And they seized the news today to attack Senator Barack Obama on his abortion rights views.

abstract: From a distance, the screaming man trapped behind the fence in front of the Holiday Inn on West 7th sounded like he was shouting, “Go home!
snippet: From a distance, the screaming man trapped behind the fence in front of the Holiday Inn on West 7th sounded like he was shouting, “Go home!
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — From a distance, the screaming man trapped behind the fence in front of the Holiday Inn on West 7th sounded like he was shouting, “Go home!” at the delegates who were leaving the Xcel Center after a short first-day session. But as the Bagger drew nearer, it was evident the man was shouting – which does not begin to describe the noise he was making – the name of Ron Paul, the libertarian and former presidential candidate.The noise that Jim Westgate of Panama City, Fla., was so comically loud – he would rear back like a banti rooster and hurl himself at the fence and the crowd – that people were reduced to laughing and smiling at the display. It was clear that this was a deeply, deeply held personal vigil and it was tough to discern what good it could possible do given that the people who were leaving were all bent on nominating John McCain later in the week. And then Dr. Jim Taylor, a delegate from the convention from Pinehurst, N.C., came over to the fence and began chatting with Mr. Westgate in between his yelps on behalf of Mr. Paul. “The work you are doing is great and I want you to know that people in the convention are doing lots of talking about Mr. Paul. Keep it up.” Not that Mr. Westgate needed the encouragement. As soon as his new friend walked away, he began yelling like crazy, hitting some new and operatic notes on behalf of his guy.

headline.main: The Carpetbagger: Shouting Down the Divide

Mr. Lenzini quickly collapsed to the floor and dissolved into convulsive laughter.

Biden Jr. has bowed out of a planned joint appearance in Manchester today, leaving Mr. Obama to “ask the people of New Hampshire to keep those impacted by Hurricane Ike in their thoughts and prayers and he will talk about the quiet storms that people across the country are facing everyday,” Jen Psaki, a campaign spokeswoman, tells us. abstract: Our own offering of what you take away from the day’s events.
snippet: Our own offering of what you take away from the day’s events.
lead_paragraph: In this final stretch of the presidential campaign, with blog posts and ads and campaign e-mails all rolling by so quickly, it seems we’re all in need of a little guidance to cut through –  as our colleague Adam Nagourney wrote this morning – the “fog” of what’s thrown up on the wall to see what sticks. This is an effort to grasp onto the meaningful. And sometimes, to offer up what’s available for laughs along the way. We’re calling this feature “Last Words,” but by no means will it be the last word of the day or night. We’ll note what’s catching our fancy, and feel free to suggest what’s caught your eye.

headline.main: Last Words: Economic Game-Changer

abstract: A man who says he was robbed by O. J. Simpson in a Las Vegas hotel room last year acknowledged in court on Tuesday that he had spoken of profiting from the incident within minutes of Mr. Simpson’s departure from the scene.
snippet: A man who says he was robbed by O. J. Simpson in a Las Vegas hotel room last year acknowledged in court on Tuesday that he had spoken of profiting from the incident within minutes of Mr. Simpson’s departure from the scene.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS  A man who says he was robbed by O. J. Simpson in a Las Vegas hotel room last year acknowledged in court on Tuesday that he had spoken of profiting from the incident within minutes of Mr. Simpson’s departure from the scene. The admission by the man, Bruce L. Fromong, contradicted his previous testimony that he had not done so.

Simpson boiled down to the prosecution and the defense debating whether Mr. Simpson aimed to steal valuable sports memorabilia or to recover personal keepsakes.

headline.print_headline: As Simpson Robbery Trial Opens, Motive Is the Focus

abstract: A panel of prominent health economists concludes that “initially there would be no real change in the number of people covered as a result of the McCain plan.”
snippet: A panel of prominent health economists concludes that “initially there would be no real change in the number of people covered as a result of the McCain plan.”
lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain’s top domestic policy adviser, former Congressional Budget Office director Douglas Holtz-Eakin, recently said in a conference call with reporters that Mr. McCain’s health care proposal would “put 25 to 30 million individuals out of the ranks of the uninsured, into the ranks of the insured.” In an article released Tuesday, a panel of prominent health economists concludes that Mr. Holtz-Eakin’s projection is off by, well, 25 to 30 million.

headline.main: Journal Disputes McCain’s Health Care Claims

headline.print_headline: F.B.I. Finds Slight Decrease In Violent Crime for 2007

abstract: The lawsuit against the Phoenix Country Club cited the club’s policy of allowing only men in its well-appointed grill room as violating the state’s civil rights act.
snippet: The lawsuit against the Phoenix Country Club cited the club’s policy of allowing only men in its well-appointed grill room as violating the state’s civil rights act.
lead_paragraph: The State Attorney General’s Office has filed a lawsuit against the Phoenix Country Club, citing the club’s policy of allowing only men in its well-appointed grill room as violating the state’s civil rights act. According to the complaint, the club’s policy of offering men one place to dine, a room with fine amenities conducive to business meetings, and women another, essentially a card room with a hotplate, is discriminatory. The suit was brought on behalf of two longtime club members, Logan Van Sittert and Barbara Van Sittert, who asked its board members in 2006 to allow women in the men’s grill. According to the complaint, Mr. and Mrs. Van Sittert were subjected to verbal abuse and threats after their inquiry, including graffiti on the golf course that referred to Mrs. Van Sittert in vulgar terms. The attorney general is seeking compensatory damages for the Van Sitterts and a permanent injunction prohibiting the club from sex-based discrimination. In a statement, the club’s board says it made several efforts to settle the matter with the attorney general outside of court but that “based on the facts and the governing case law,” the statement reads, “we are confident that the matter will be resolved appropriately in that venue.”

headline.main: Attorney General Sues Arizona Country Club

lead_paragraph: We’ve all heard it countless times, but that old adage, “It’s the economy, stupid,” courtesy of Democratic political strategist James Carville, seems to have just as much relevance in the closing weeks of the 2008 campaign as it did during the 1992 election. Whether it will work for the Democrats this year remains an open question. What is certain is that the candidates now find themselves competing on a playing field that has been dramatically reshaped by the economic turmoil of recent weeks, and they’re scrambling to recast their messages to voters.

Hundreds of vehicles had lined up on both sides, some waiting hours for the bridge to open a few minutes after 5 a.m. Then they inched, bumper to bumper, onto the new $234 million, 10-lane span. The old bridge collapsed into the Mississippi River on Aug. 1, 2007, killing 13 people and injuring 145.

abstract: Agriprocessors Inc., an embattled kosher meatpacker with a plant in Postville, Iowa, named a corporate lawyer from New York to be its chief executive, responding to an ultimatum from the leading kosher certifying organization.

lead_paragraph: Agriprocessors Inc., an embattled kosher meatpacker with a plant in Postville, Iowa, named a corporate lawyer from New York to be its chief executive, responding to an ultimatum from the leading kosher certifying organization. The executive, Bernard S. Feldman, 63, was described by Agriprocessors’ owner, Aaron Rubashkin, as a turnaround expert who would restore production to its levels before a May 12 immigration raid. Last week, after Iowa authorities brought criminal charges for child labor violations against Mr. Rubashkin and his son Sholom, the Orthodox Union, the nation’s most prominent kosher certifier, threatened to withdraw its seal of approval unless a new chief executive was named. In a statement, the Orthodox Union praised Mr. Feldman and said “there is now a foundation in place for restoring confidence” in the company. JULIA PRESTON

abstract: Lt. Gov. Sean Parnell of Alaska conceded to Representative Don Young in the Republican primary for Alaska’s only House seat.
snippet: Lt. Gov. Sean Parnell of Alaska conceded to Representative Don Young in the Republican primary for Alaska’s only House seat.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. Sean Parnell of Alaska conceded to Representative Don Young in the Republican primary for Alaska’s only House seat. Mr. Parnell lost to Mr. Young by just 304 votes, and he initially signaled he would request a recount. But on Thursday, the day the state certified the results of the Aug. 26 primary, Mr. Parnell said he trusted the work of election officials and did not want to spend the state money on a recount. Mr. Parnell was endorsed for the House seat by Gov. Sarah Palin, the Republican nominee for vice president. He would succeed her as governor if she is elected. Mr. Young, who has held the seat for 35 years, is under investigation as part of a broad federal inquiry into Alaska government and politics. Mr. Young now faces Ethan Berkowitz, a Democrat who leads him in state polls. WILLIAM YARDLEY

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  He lived a solitary life, working long days and long nights as the engineer of a commuter train that crawled across Southern California, making stop after routine stop. He loved trains, so much that he encouraged teenagers who showed their own enthusiasm for the rails, exchanging text messages while he was at work, one boy asserted last week. That, the authorities say, may have contributed to the worst California train disaster in 50 years.

abstract: In early July, both candidates were thought to be running positive campaigns. Not anymore, according to the latest Times/CBS News poll.
snippet: In early July, both candidates were thought to be running positive campaigns. Not anymore, according to the latest Times/CBS News poll.
lead_paragraph: Months of aggressive campaigning by both candidates have significantly altered the way voters perceive them – Senator John McCain is largely seen as someone who is spending more of his time attacking his opponent than spelling out what he would do as president, while Senator Barack Obamacontinues to be seen as a candidate who is spending more of his time explaining what he would do as president rather than attacking his opponent, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. This was not the case earlier this summer. In early July, both candidates were thought to berunning positive campaigns.In the latest poll, a majority of voters, 56 percent, said Mr. Obama is spending his time making it clear what he would do if elected, rather than attacking the Republican candidate. Most voters say the opposite of Mr. McCain. Only 38 percent of those polled said Mr. McCain was explaining what he would do as president, while 53 percent said he was attacking Mr. Obama. In July, 63 percent of the voters surveyed said Mr. McCain was running a positive campaign.

lead_paragraph: Two liberal groups – one of them directed by a brother of the Democratic Party chairman Howard Dean – will begin running a graphic attack advertisement Thursday morning raising questions about Senator John McCain’s health. Showing vivid and unflattering images of the fresh scar that appeared on Senator McCain’s face immediately after his last operation for melanoma skin cancer eight years ago, the commercial ends with a screen headline that reads, “Why won’t John McCain release his medical records?” (Mr. McCain, 72, did invite a limited group of reporters to inspect more than 1,100 pages of his medical records in May, though he gave them only a three-hour window in which to review the documents.)
